subsc: Agro-industry, marketing, and trade,General agriculture, fishing and forestry sector,Other social services,Central government administration,General transportation sector

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of this project is
            rated as satisfactory. The overall sustainability rating of
            the project is uncertain because of the numerous risk
            factors still existing and because project activities cannot
            be expanded without a new project. However, there are
            positive factors for sustainability: The Government is
            systematically following the market-oriented policies put in
            place nearly a decade ago. These policies have removed most
            of the disincentives to increasing agricultural production,
            and emphasized greater transparency, accountability, and
            private-sector involvement in development of the rural
            sector. The overall performances by the World Bank and the
            Borrower were both rated satisfactory. Lessons learned
            included the following: a pilot project will not give all
            the lessons needed and the design of the first follow-on
            must be flexible enough to allow for corrective actions.
            Linking of the nutrition and micro-project components and a
            community approach was essential for the success of this
            project. Implementation of food security and other programs
            using micro-projects can be trusted to local nongovernmental
            organizations, but it is possible only if the government has
            a positive attitude toward NGOs and allows that borrowed
            funds can be disbursed for their programs. Strict selection
            criteria needs to be applied when admitting NGOs into the
            program. Early and firm action must be taken when NGOs are
            failing or are misusing financing opportunities.
